full_text: The US economy just had another robust year: 2024
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text: The US economy grew 2.5% over the past year, according to new Commerce Department figures released Thursday, comparing the fourth quarter in 2024 with the one from a year earlier. A resilient labor market supported strong consumer spending last year. Americans’ spending accounts for about 70% of the US economy. Business investment also fueled growth in 2024, though it went into reverse in the final months of the year.\n\nThe economy expanded at an annualized rate of 2.3% in the fourth quarter, as measured by gross domestic product, the broadest measure of economic output. That was slightly below economists’ expectations of a 2.4% rate, according to FactSet. The figures are adjusted for seasonal swings and inflation.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text:
Trump Tariffs have become a grim reality, for the markets , geopolitics and economies, globally. Elevated levels of global markets , the widespread and elevated nature of tariffs, and the brazen statements of TrumpPolitics ,including once again asking Canada to become the 51st State of the USA, are combining to roil risk sentiments, across the board. 
The second order effects of the tariffs, after the initial fall of stocks , are competitive currency devaluations by exporters led by China. 
The third order effects will be intense dumping of goods produced by the already excess capacity afflicted Chinese economy .
 A doom loop starts for global economies and markets start going down in anticipation. 
Trump 2.0 fears are at the front and centre of the plate today and safe haven buying of gold, Swiss franc, Yen will be the only place to hide, in these Tariff wars induced, risk off fire storm . Ajay Bagga 7 AM India , Feb 3rd 2025 .
name: Ajay Bagga

name: Ajay Bagga

full_text:
China gets a Trump Challenge which is still only a small portion of the 60% tariffs he had talked off. 
China has a Significant debt, a property bubble, underwhelming domestic consumption  and trade pressures , all of which are part of the structural weaknesses in China’s  economy that stimulus packages cannot resolve alone.
But Chinese policy makers have analysed all Trump scenarios and you can expect a multi fold response from China, including taking Trump to the WTO ( wont make a difference), relooking at relocation of supply chains ( EU supplying Russia through Central Asian ex Soviet republics model is there ) , denying critical mineral supplies , Dumping its excess capacity ex US , opening more concessions with a divided EU and looking at stimulating domestic consumption .
All and more will come.
On the currency front, China will depreciate its currency to offset the 10% tariffs.
It will support its stock market.
Restructuring of property firms' debt to be expected.
No Plaza Accord 2025 (which destroyed Japanese growth momentum in the 1980s-2000s)...that message is very clear to Chinese policy makers.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text:
Trump paused the tariffs on America’s neighbors after  Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum and Canadian Prime Minister Justin  Trudeau made commitments, some of which they’d already made, to bolster  security at their respective borders with the United States.

“I just spoke with President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico. It  was a very friendly conversation wherein she agreed to immediately  supply 10,000 Mexican Soldiers on the Border separating Mexico and the  United States,” Trump wrote on Truth Social earlier Monday.

“These soldiers will be specifically designated to stop the  flow of fentanyl, and illegal migrants into our country,” he wrote.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text: “Canada has agreed to ensure we have a secure Northern Border, and to  finally end the deadly scourge of drugs like Fentanyl that have been  pouring into our Country, killing hundreds of thousands of Americans,  while destroying their families and communities all across our Country,”  Trump posted.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text:
The Wall Street Journal had delivered a blistering critique  of the Trump tariffs in a weekend editorial entitled: “The dumbest trade  war in history.”

When asked the about market reaction — and the Wall Street  Journal’s editorial — Trump demurred on Monday when signing executive  actions in the Oval Office.

“Not only is it not dumb, you’re going to see, you’re going  to see every single one of those countries is dying to make a deal,” he  said, sitting feet away from Rupert Murdoch, whose newspaper empire  includes the Journal.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text: Posted by Justin Trudeau :\nI just had a good call with President Trump. Canada is implementing our $1.3 billion border plan — reinforcing the border with new choppers, technology and personnel, enhanced coordination with our American partners, and increased resources to stop the flow of fentanyl. Nearly 10,000 frontline personnel are and will be working on protecting the border.   In addition, Canada is making new commitments to appoint a Fentanyl Czar, we will list cartels as terrorists, ensure 24/7 eyes on the border, launch a Canada- U.S. Joint Strike Force to combat organized crime, fentanyl and money laundering. I have also signed a new intelligence directive on organized crime and fentanyl and we will be backing it with $200 million.   Proposed tariffs will be paused for at least 30 days while we work together.
name: Ajay Bagga

The Canadian dollar and Mexican peso rebounded as leaders from the neighboring US countries said they’d struck deals with President Donald Trump to delay tariffs for one month.

The loonie, as Canada’s currency is known, surged more than 1% late in the Monday session — reversing an earlier 1.7% slide — after Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said new US tariffs would be paused 30 days after a call with the US leader. The peso was was up 1.5% after Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum earlier said the nation had struck a similar standstill accord. It had earlier weakened by 3% against the dollar.

full_text: Gold rose to a record high, after advancing by almost 1% in the previous session, as the opening salvos of the US-China trade war stoked haven demand.\n\nBullion reached an all-time peak of $2,848.27 an ounce on Wednesday. That came after President Donald Trump hit Chinese imports with a 10% tariff the day before, prompting a swift but more targeted retaliation from Beijing.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text:
US tariffs on China came into force on Tuesday.
China has had a muted response.
China is being restrained because it “has more to lose,” due to its huge trade imbalance with the US.
The question now is whether leaders of the world’s two biggest economies can quickly reach an agreement.
Chinese officials enter talks with less bargaining room. The Asian manufacturing powerhouse exports over three times more goods to the US than it buys.
China’s options range from promises to buy more American oil and gas, and keeping the yuan stable, to delivering on the Phase One deal, an agreement signed in 2020.
For now, Beijing is striking a balancing act between looking strong while not upping the ante.
We might be seeing two giants, sizing each up and testing each other’s resolve, while also playing to their domestic audiences, before shaking hands, so both portray an eventual deal as a "victory" .
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text:
Countries and companies are studying the experience of Trump’s first presidency, and are playing down the risk of a full blown international tariff war, saying the US president had not carried through on threats of additional levies against its trading partners.
It remains an extreme form of Game Theory, without the actors knowing , who is playing which game, and moving on estimates of each actors' Red Lines and Non Negotiables .
Markets suffer in such periods of uncertainty and volatility.
Markets are being wise in ignoring the posturing and focussing on the "on the ground actions" .
When unpredicted outcomes hit in such a complacent scenario, expect extreme moves.
For now, markets are moving up, assessing that Trump is a lot of Threats and Extreme Talk with more Moderate Action and Palatable Outcomes.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text: The global automotive supply chain is so complex and interconnected that a component made in Mexico could end up at an American plant before going back to Mexico for final assembly and then being sold to the US market — which could result in “a tariff-on-tariff” situation.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text:
Global Markets Update: Navigating Tariffs, Yields, and Economic Signals
Ajay Bagga Feb 6th 7 AM India Time:
Global markets exhibited a measured rebound mid-week, with steady gains across equities and bonds reflecting a temporary sense of calm after earlier volatility. The fluctuations were largely driven by renewed trade tensions as former U.S. President Donald Trump reintroduced elements of his tariff agenda, reigniting concerns about global trade dynamics.

Trump Tariffs: A Renewed Trade Headwind

The reimposition of tariffs by Trump has stirred apprehension in global markets, particularly impacting sectors sensitive to international trade. While the initial shock triggered sharp market reactions, investors appear to be recalibrating their expectations, recognizing that the actual economic fallout may take time to materialize. Market participants are closely monitoring potential retaliatory measures from major trading partners, which could further disrupt supply chains and corporate earnings.

US Bond Yields: A Barometer of Economic Sentiment

U.S. Treasury yields have been notably volatile, reflecting shifting investor sentiment amid evolving economic data and policy expectations. The benchmark 10-year yield has oscillated as traders digest mixed signals—balancing concerns over growth with expectations for Federal Reserve policy adjustments. A recent drift lower in yields suggests a flight to safety, underscoring investor caution as geopolitical and economic uncertainties loom.

US Jobs Data: A Crucial Indicator for Fed Policy

Attention is sharply focused on Friday’s U.S. jobs report, a critical data point that could influence the Federal Reserve's monetary policy trajectory. Strong employment figures may reinforce expectations of continued policy tightening, while weaker data could bolster the case for a more dovish stance. The labor market's resilience has been a cornerstone of the U.S. economic narrative, and any deviation from this trend will likely have ripple effects across asset classes.

Commodity Prices: Reflecting Supply-Demand Crosscurrents

Commodity markets have been equally dynamic, with prices responding to both macroeconomic factors and specific supply-demand imbalances. Oil prices remain sensitive to geopolitical developments, including Middle East tensions and OPEC+ production strategies. Meanwhile, industrial metals have been caught between global growth concerns and supply chain disruptions, while agricultural commodities face volatility driven by weather patterns and trade policy shifts.

Broad Market Overview: Seeking Stability Amid Uncertainty

Despite the week’s initial turbulence, U.S. equity markets closed higher on Wednesday as investors looked past trade-related turmoil. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.7%, the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2%, and the S&P 500 advanced 0.4%. This rebound highlights the market’s resilience, though underlying caution persists. Volatility has been the prevailing theme, with market participants striving to find equilibrium amid shifting economic signals and policy uncertainties.

In summary, global markets are navigating a complex landscape marked by trade tensions, fluctuating bond yields, pivotal economic data, and commodity price volatility. Investors remain vigilant, balancing short-term market reactions with long-term economic fundamentals as they assess the evolving macroeconomic environment.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text: Bank of England cuts base rate by 25 bps to 4.5%
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text:
The Bank of England cut interest rates Thursday in a bid to boost Britain's sluggish economy, although inflation pressures remained elevated.

The BOE cut its benchmark Bank Rate by 25 basis points, to 4.5% from 4.75%, easing rates for only the third time since just after the start of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020.

BOE officials voted unanimously to reduce the key rate, after having voted 6-3 in December to keep policy unchanged.

The UK economy has barely grown since mid-2024, and potential headwinds are growing following finance minister Rachel Reeves' tax increases for employers as well as the risk of a global trade war led by US President Donald Trump.

However, Governor Andrew Bailey and his colleagues are in a difficult situation given inflationary pressures remain strong.

Inflation stood at 2.5% in December, above the BoE's 2% target, and higher domestic fuel costs could push consumer prices further upwards in the coming months.

Investors are pricing at least three quarter-point cuts by the end of 2025, and Bailey is likely to continue expressing a cautious data-dependent approach to future policy.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text: Indian markets have discounted a 25 bps rate cut by the RBI today. Inflation is expected to average 4.5% in Q4 FY2025, versus an average of 4.8% in the entire financial year 2024-2025. Next year, inflation is expected to be slightly lower , in the range of 4.2-4.5% . There is space for RBI to cut rates today ,given the lowering of the fiscal deficit in the Union Budget 2025. Globally, the economic growth is expected to be strong in the range of 3% to 3.25% . The Bank of Canada , Bank of England and ECB have all cut rates over the last week while the US Fed stood pat . The Bank of Japan has raised rates and has given indications of further raising rates to 1% over the next two quarters. Add to this the overlay of Trump Tariffs, which inject the uncertainty of protectionism , inflation and sharp currency moves. This raises the chance that the RBI could pause for now and wait for the initial months of Trump 2.0 to pass. We feel RBI will seize the chance to cut today, will provide more liquidity to the money markets and will keep its inflation and GDP growth targets in line with the recent Union Budget and Economic Survey. The Rupee depreciation has to be seen in a global scenario. The share of imports in India's consumption basket is around 12% . That gets impact by a lower Rupee, but offsetting this are the gains for the goods and services exports of $ 700 billion . Keeping rates at these elevated levels will not protect the rupee but will prove a continued pressure point for the Indian economy . Hence we expect a pragmatic rate cut by the RBI and three more rate cuts in the rest of the calendar year. The impact on the markets will be muted , as a rate cut is largely factored in by the markets .
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text: Global Markets and India Update: Ajay Bagga, Market Veteran, Feb 19th, 8 AM India time  :                                                                                              Senior officials from the US and Russia met for 4 hours in Riyadh to kick start Ukraine-Russia peace talks. US Sec of State Rubio subsequently briefed senior diplomats from France, Germany, Italy, Britain and the EU. On the monetary front, the Reserve Bank of Australia cut rates for the first time in four years, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand has cut rates by 50 bps this morning and the Bank Indonesia is expected to hold rates steady . The FOMC meeting minutes today will provide some insights into the Fed thought process. Overall, global investors, governments and corporations are in a "hold and wait" mode , as they wade through the cross-currents of geopolitical risk reduction with possible peace deals in Ukraine and the on going Middle East ceasefire extension, while facing up to changes in global supply chains and trade flows due to some form of tariffs from the Trump administration. Emerging markets debt and Chinese tech stocks are the two favoured long trades , as are physical Gold and silver based funds. More Chinese stimulus measures are expected as the NPC meets . Meanwhile, US stocks saw the S&P 500 eke out a small gain to mark another all time high level. In Fed speak,Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker, Governors Michelle Bowman and Christopher Waller reiterated that US economic strength and elevated inflation warrant holding the policy rate steady for the time being.\nSan Francisco Fed President Mary Daly concurred that a pause in rate cuts is appropriate until more visible progress is made toward bringing inflation down to the Fed's 2% goal.  In big brokerage calls, Goldman gave a thumbs up to Chinese stocks, Bank of America warned that US stock outperformance could be on its last surge before a correction later in the year, Citi and Morgan Stanley brought out positive reports on the Indian markets, calling for 26,000 levels for the Nifty by Dec 2025 on the back of structural strength and corporate capex/releveraging gaining traction. For now Indian markets are in a tight pattern, with a higher probability of a near term break downwards on the back of sustained FPI selling pressures.The Indian midcap indices are down nearly 18% from the September peaks while the small and microcap indices are already in bear market territory. The lead indices, the Nifty 50 and BSE Sensex are both down around 13% from the September all time highs, marking 5 months of negative returns. The key question is , is this a correction within a structural bull market, or is a bear market imminent? Bear markets in India since 1991 have lasted around 12 months on average , the longest being around 26 months long . Bull markets last around 48-56 months, the one that peaked in September had marked 54 months . In retrospect we can draw clean lines and patterns, but looking ahead , we see a challenge to markets from the rapid cross-currents of geopolitical risk, tariff wars, competitive currency devaluations and stubborn inflation which could worsen due to policy protectionism . Q3 earnings are pointing to sub 10% profit and topline growth, with SMID stocks more impacted given their strong correlation with domestic economic growth. Significant policy stimulus and easing measures are needed in this scenario to lift growth and earnings, but these are lacking so far. In that scenario we see further downsides rather than a recovery in Indian stocks and FPI flows.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text:
Fortunate to have met many policy makers in India over the recent weeks.  
The amount of relentless , resilient work going on in India is amazing . 
I don’t make political statements . 
I have no interest other than National Interest . 
India is transforming . 
Transforming a massive continent is not easy but it’s happening . 
We have to benefit from this . 
The learned men of the markets point out what all is wrong , that we are over valued , that there is demand destruction , that buy and hold is a foolish strategy. 
For them maybe it’s true . 
For the rest of us it’s much more profitable to cut the noise, allocate to the India story and to stay put.  
We will never catch the market tops and the market troughs . It’s enough to catch the average India growth . 
That itself , compounding relentlessly is enough for financial liberation . 
Make it work . 
Investing works , superior analysis and proving one is smarter then most of the crowd is a good ego booster .
Optimists make money and progress . Invest , stay invested . Benefit from India’s growth.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text:
[08:49, 10/3/2025] Ajay Bagga: 
Data heavy weak with expected volatility. 
The Trump "Threaten/Levy Tariffs/ Roll back/ Threaten afresh" cycle is roiling market sentiment and destroying US goodwill and soft power at an accelerating speed. 
Europen welfare states are rebooting into warfare states . 
China has levied retaliatory tariffs not only on the US but also on Canada. Canada has got an ex Goldman Sachs, and ex Bank of England and Bank of Canada Governor as its newly minted Prime Minister . 
Steel and Aluminium tariffs of 25% come due on March 12th in the US, South Korean steel majors are falling sharply as no relief is yet on the horizon.
 Add on China facing deflation, not only in the struggling and oversupplied Producer Prices, but even in the "cant spend,wont spend, shant make me spend" Chinese consumption basket.
 Second order impacts of the tariffs, in terms of worsening business outllooks and consumer sentiments, threat of inflation, threat to economic growth and the geopolitical risk of a NATO retreat by the US, are now becoming visible, but in unexpected ways like a weakening US dollar and a falling US market.
 What will China do on the ground is the most pertinent question. 
Will it depreciate the Yuan as it did in 2018-19 , leading to a stock market crash, or will it play a long game, choosing its fights and its fighting fronts ?

 Trump faces a government funding shutdown on the 14th , where the Democrats are not ready to play ball on the September temporary funding plan put forth by the House Speaker Johnson .
 That will lead to more uncertainty, with complacent markets saying, "They posture and then kick the can down the road, dont worry" .
 What if the Democrats say this is enough, we will not play ball? No one has taken that into the equation so far.
 US CPI and PPI numbers this week will be watched for signs of consumer distress as well as rising prices .
 Indian markets are in a shadow of this global polycrises in the making, and we cant expect a sustainable bottom formation,till there is a semblance of order restored in global economic relations and geopolitics.
 Time to stay cautious and invest fresh funds in a slow format to allow the markets time to discount the Trump Multifront Disruptions .
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text: Classic economic setup in India.  Below trend growth , middling capacity utilization, contained inflation , global overhang of US tariffs and China dumping . Restrictive monetary policy needs to be eased quickly . It will take 9-12 months for the easing to flow through the economy. \nExpect a rate cut in April and two more rate cuts in short order thereafter .
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text:
Gold surges above $3,000 for the first time as investors seek a haven from Trump tariffs
We have seen Gold taking pauses when it crossed 1000 and 2000 $ . 
The outlook is strong but Long on Gold is too consensus a trade for comfort . 
Recency bias strong in Gold.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text: The S&P 500′s rapid 10% decline from a record high into correction territory has wiped out trillions of dollars in market value.\nThe market value of the S&P 500 at its Feb 19 peak was $52.06 trillion.Thursday’s decline put the index’s market value down to $46.78 trillion.\nTotal value eroded $5.2 trillion.
name: Ajay Bagga

full_text: Moody's Ratings agency has elevated Greece's long-term sovereign rating to Baa3 from Ba1, effectively upgrading the nation's status to investment grade. The agency also revised Greece's outlook from positive to stable.\nMoody's anticipates that Greece will maintain surpluses and reduce its high debt burden due to the successful implementation of institutional reforms and a stable political environment.
name: Ajay Bagga
